context: [3] Each marker represents a single measurement, and there are only a small number of instances, mostly around 5.05Â° North, 117.8Â° [4] East, where several points overlay each other. [1] Fig. 2 shows that the differences in emission rates in NOx and isoprene between the rainforest and the oil palm plantations give rise to differences in concentrations throughout the boundary layer and into the free troposphere. [2] Over the rainforest, median boundary layer mixing ratios of NO, NO2, and isoprene were 35, 161, and 767 parts per trillion (1012) by volume (pptv), respectively, and over the plantation the median mixing ratios were 67, 288, and 3870 pptv, respectively. [3] Surprisingly, ozone concentrations were similar over both landscapes in the boundary layer (rainforest: 11 ppbv; oil palm plantation: 12 ppbv). [4] The ozone measurements at the Bukit Atur Global Atmosphere Watch station confirm that our measurement period is typical of the long-term record at this site. [5] However, the concentrations of peroxyacetyl nitrate (PAN) increased from 6 pptv in the boundary layer over the rainforest to 12 pptv over the plantation landscape, demonstrating enhanced photochemical processing of the increased NOx and VOC emissions and concentrations over the plantations.
